newsitem.title: USA: Labor nominee may have skirted the law, Lott says.
newsitem.headline: Labor nominee may have skirted the law, Lott says.

text.p: Senate Republican Leader Trent Lott said on Tuesday that Alexis Herman, President Clinton's nominee to be labour secretary, might have come close to violating the law in her work as a White House official.
Lott was commenting on Herman's reported role in arranging private fund-raising meetings between Clinton and Vice President Al Gore and corporate executives.

Congressional Republicans say the nominations of Herman and Transportation Secretary-designate Rodney Slater could be in for a rough time in Senate confirmation hearings because of questions about apparent involvement in political activities.

"This latest information that has come out about arranging for meetings, appointments to the White House ... gets awfully close to the edge of violating the Hatch Act," Lott said, referring to a law barring government officials from partisan activities.
Lott said he did not know if Herman's nomination was in jeopardy and had thought she was a good choice for labour secretary.
"I think we have to take a look at what she did and see if there are any problems," he said. "I hope there are not."
He said Herman's activity "certainly on its face appears bad judgment" and senators had to determine if it was anything more than that.
